awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Software Hardware Architecture Co-Design for Smart Environment Operation and Management
awd_abstract_narration:
"Internet-of-Things" (IoT) embedded with sensing, actuation, computing, communication and storage resources are expected to transform our homes, offices, neighborhoods and communities into "smart environment", providing novel functions, services and creating potential economic impacts in trillions. Despite recent booming IoT business, there is a lack of foundational software/hardware architecture suitable for fine grained access, performance assurances and management critically demanded in smart environment. This research takes a principled approach to design and develop such a software/hardware architecture serving as a foundation for future IoT technology and applications, thus alleviating some of the critical technical obstacles impeding the trillions of economic potentials in diverse IoT applications. The PI will collaborate with the police and industry partners for technology pilots to assist officers for agile emergency response in their daily duties, and seniors to age at home with improved life quality. Students from Ph.D., M.S., to undergraduate and high school levels will be involved and trained during the research. Outreach to K-12 and local communities will leverage the research prototypes for science projects and maker's clubs to foster a culture of technology and innovation.

This research promotes smart object command operations as first class citizens. It will develop software/hardware architecture and systems firmly rooted in flexible, fine-grained access, command execution assurances and scalable management demanded in smart environment. States and information related to access constraints are bundled into self-sufficient and self-protected command data units. The research will explore and develop mechanisms to ensure formal IoT command execution properties; essential hardware traffic forwarding and security functions to ensure low latency and protection of IoT operations; and configuration, monitoring, maintenance essential in smart environment management.

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to develop foundational Internet-of-Things (IoT) software and hardware in large scale smart environments that match the unique requirements and characteristics of ``smart objects/IoT.” Smart objects embedded with actuation, computing, communication and storage resources will transform our homes, offices, neighborhoods, enterprises and communities into ``smart environment,’’ providing novel functions, services and creating enormous economic impacts. Although products such as smart door locks have already appeared on the market, how to control, management such smart objects at large scale (e.g., thousands or even tens of thousands in a university campus, a large corporation, or a city), is a huge challenge.

This project has produced fundamental research work along multiple directions of IoT software and hardware for large scale smart environments:

Flexible, fine-grained access control for IoT devices in enterprise environments where tens of thousands of users need to access smart objects at a similar or larger order of magnitude. We built an IoT access control system which achieves robust, fine-grained access control and responsive execution at enterprise scale, using secure, unforgeable tokens so that users can operate on individuals or collections of objects in a single operation. It provides centralized policy, easy to manage from one location, and distributed execution, without any bottleneck in commands and operations. Compared with conventional systems using access control list, we eliminate or reduce by 10x to 100x the updating overhead under frequent changes of subject memberships and policies, which happen frequently under large scale IoT environments.

In IoT operations, it is common that certain preconditions must be met before users can execute commands, for sake of safety, correctness or efficiency. E.g., before turning on the water sprinklers, power outlets must be shut off to avoid electricity shock. Manual tracking and ensuring such preconditions can be error-prone, unsafe and slow. We propose APEX, a system automatically deducing all the preconditions and executing respective pre-commands given a user command. It has two execution strategies, a conservative one that favors higher overall success rates the command, and an aggressive one that favors speed. We proved the system ensures consistency under multiple concurrent commands, atomicity with all-or-nothing outcome, and robustness to recover from failures.

In IoT, what services from which nearby devices are available, must be discovered by a user’s device (e.g., smartphone) before commands are issued. Service visibility scoping in large scale, enterprise environments has multiple unique requirements: depending on the attributes of devices of the user, which device features can be access by which user differs (e.g., a manager can find and access a VIP conference room, but not the group members). Existing solutions are insufficient to offer such differentiated visibility scoping. We built Argus, a distributed approach offering three-level, fine-grained visibility scoping: i) Level 1 public visibility where services are identically visible to everyone; ii) Level 2 differentiated visibility where service visibility depends on users’ non-sensitive attributes; iii) Level 3 covert visibility where service visibility depends on users’ sensitive attributes that are never explicitly disclosed. Argus is proved with theoretical assurance, and validated on a testbed to show sub-second discovery for all services, proving its applicability to large scale enterprise IoT environments.

Data sharing among IoT devices is a frequent needs (e.g., vehicles sharing sensing data to ensure no perception gaps despite occluded pedestrians and other vehicles), yet the current wireless communication falls short of the needs for high speed, low loss, one to many communication. WiFi radios in broadcast has a mere 6Mbps low data rate, and losses can be as high as 80%. We developed V-MAC, a revolutionary radio multicast technology, that adopts a publish/subscribe abstraction at the medium access control (MAC) level of radios. Instead of sending to one pre-known point (or neighbor radio), V-MAC radios send data with names not bound to any particular point. Any neighbor radios that need matching data can receive them based on name filtering. Such receiver-initiated pub/sub communication achieves late, on-the-fly binding: each neighbor decides whether and how it should respond based on the desired data’s attributes; no prior discovery nor determination of destination group or node addresses is needed. Combined with selective requests for commonly missing data, V-MAC running on software-modified WiFi dongles can achieve 50Mbps goodput at 10% loss in one-to-many communication, one order of magnitude improvements compared to WiFi broadcast. This will support real time data sharing among autonomous vehicles and robots for collaborative work.
